ABOUT ME \\ Olga Chernomor, PhD

WHY WHY WHY?


I blame (read thank) my elder sister Yuliia;) She "played" Maths with me before I learned to read. I also blame her to motivate me to learn English. Eventually, I also blame my parents, who got me a book "Encyclopedia of Professor Fortran", when I was around 4 years old. My first "computer" was printed on page 70 of that book and I would fiercely "type" my first code on the keyboard printed on page 71. I'm serious, by the way!

Well, after some considerations, now it all makes sence!

I'm a trained mathematician (even got two Master degrees, just to be sure). I also have "some" programming experience (the actual first code was written in Pascal though). English. Well, my C++ has less bugs than my English, but people seem to understand, what I mean. I'm sure that the book's characters: the Professor, the Cat, the Caterpillar and the Sparrow, explain 99.9% of my choice to get a PhD degree in Bioinformatics with a focus in phylogenetics and species evolution. So, everything is connected!

In summary, I love working with complex abstract concepts, comming up with algorithms and developing methods and software to tackle biologically inspired problems. I appreciate clear though informative visualisation in science and tech communication and also enjoy technical writing. Overall, I'm feeling myself extremely lucky to work at the interface of so many desciplinces intertwined in bioinformatics.

Research \\ Selected projects

P1 \\ Phylogenetic Terraces

In phylogenomics a phylogenetic tree is inferred using information from multiple loci/genes (generally called partitions).

If some gene sequences are missing, they are denoted by stretches of dashes in corresponding gene multiple sequence alignment (MSA).
In the presence of missing sequences for each partition there is an associated induced partition tree.

Induced partition tree is obtained from a given complete tree by deleting species with missing sequences for this partition.

Then the score of a complete tree is computed from the set of its induced partition trees.
If two trees, despite beeing topologically different, induce the same set of induced partition trees, their scores are identical1. (1: likelihood score under general partition model and also parsimony score)

A collection of trees, which induce the same set induced partition trees.
Development of methods for studying and handling of Phylogenetic Terraces (phylogenomics)

In Phylogenetics we are interested in inferring an evolutionary tree for a set of species using genetic sequence information. In a classical analysis, an input is a multiple sequence alignment (MSA) consisting of a single gene/locus. With an advancement of sequencing technologies contemporary analyses shifted to datasets comprising of multiple genes/loci.

With hundreds and thousands of genes considered, some sequences for some species are missing:

  • some sequences should be excluded due to their quality;
  • if non-model species are included in the analysis, some of their sequences might be absent, because they are yet to be sequenced;
  • but more importantly, gene sequences might be missing due to biological diversity of species as a result of gene gains and losses.

Therefore, missing data is the intrinsic property of big contemporary datasets.

It was shown that if missing data

Keywords: phylogenomics, supermatrix, missing data, phylogenetic terraces
Bioinformatic Tools: MAFFT, SEQ-GEN, IQ-TREE, RAxML
Data: DNA/protein sequences, multiple-sequence alignments, presence-absence matrices, simulated and biological datasets
Tech/DEV: linux, MacOS, C++, R, bash, git, HPC/grid clusters
Publications:
  • O. Chernomor, B.Q. Minh, and A. von Haeseler (2015) Consequences of Common Topological Rearrangements for Partition Trees in Phylogenomic Inference. J. Comput. Biol., 22, 1129-1142.
  • O. Chernomor, A. von Haeseler, and B.Q. Minh (2016) Terrace Aware Data Structure for Phylogenomic Inference from Supermatrices. Syst. Biol., 65, 997-1008.

P2 \\ Evolution of light-dependent protochlorophyllide oxidoreductases (LPORs)

Protein evolution: Evolution of light-dependent protochlorophyllide oxidoreductases (LPORs) in aerobic anoxygenic phototrophs
Keywords: protein evolution, LPORs, horizontal gene transfer
Bioinformatic Tools: MAFFT, HMMER, BLAST, REvolver, IQ-TREE, RAxML, TNT, MrBayes, NOTUNG, ITOL, FigTree
Data: DNA/RNA/protein sequences, biological dataset
Databases: ensembl, GenBank, CAMERA, oneKP, SilVa
Tech/DEV: linux, MacOS, R, bash, grid cluster, custom pipelines
Publications:
  • O. Chernomore, L. Peterse, J. Schneidewinde, A. Loeschcke, E. Knieps-Grünhagen, F. Schmitz, E. von Lieres, R.J. Kutta, V. Svensson, K.-E. Jaeger, T. Drepper, A. von Haeseler, and U. Krauss (in press) Complex evolution of light-dependent protochlorophyllide oxidoreductases in aerobic anoxygenic phototrophs: origin, phylogeny and function. Mol. Biol. Evol., 37, in press. e contributed equally

P3 \\ Tracing evolution of brain-expressed genes

Human brain evolution: Tracing changes of non-synonymous to synonymous evolutionary rates along the evolutionary trees in primates
Keywords: protein-coding gene evolution, dN/dS, modern human brain evolution, ancient human
Bioinformatic Tools: vcftools, bedtools, gatk, PRANK, IQ-TREE, PAML, ITOL
Data: DNA/protein sequences,VCF files, biological dataset
Databases: ensembl, OMA Orthology database
Tech/DEV: linux, R, bash, grid cluster, custom pipelines
Publications:
  • J. Kaczanowska, F. Ganglberger, O. Chernomor, B. Galik, A. Hess, Y. Moodley, A. von Haeseler, K. Bühler, W. Haubensak (in prep) Molecular archaeology of the human brain.
